Devery Horton, 3rd Grader at Freedom Elementary, has won the July Summer Cooking Competition

"My creation is a chocolate cupcake with a graham cracker bottom and lime frosting on the top. And a sprinkle of graham cracker and a lime twist on top. I used chocolate in the cupcake batter. The graham crackers were smashed with butter and pushed down just like I do with cheesecake, except in cupcake papers. I used my buttercream frosting recipe but I squeezed lime into it. I also put green food coloring in it to help the judges remember the lime flavor. You can't see the avocado but it is in the batter. It works the same as oil if you smash it up a lot. It looks gross but you can't even taste it. The cupcakes taste really good and I wish you could taste one too, especially the crunchy part on the bottom. The contest is fun and maybe next year we can do it in person. Thank you."

BUILDING THE FUTURE

Beginning this school year, students will have the opportunity to build tiny homes as part of our construction classes being offered at the Weber Innovation Center.

A workshop is currently being erected on site thanks to some very generous donations from the community. Hogan Construction and Gevena Rock donated all the concrete work. The project also received a $10,000 donation from The Clark and Christine Ivory Foundation to purchase tools and equipment.

It's anticipated nearly 100 students will participate in the design and building of tiny homes through our construction, interior design and STEM engineering classes.

A big thanks to all the volunteers and donors who have made this project possible!

SHORTENED SCHOOL DAYS

Earlier this summer, we sent out a survey out to parents to get their feedback on reopening schools. Almost 11,000 parents responded and nearly 25% of them expressed interest in online learning.

In order to provide flexible learning options for families, we will be shortening the school schedule for first quarter by 45 minutes each day. This will give teachers valuable time every day to provide online instruction to their students who may be learning from home. It will also give our custodial staff extra time to clean and sanitize our buildings.

Following our Safe Weber Framework, other adjustments to the schedule may be necessary if circumstances change. For more information on our reopening plans, please visit:

https://wsd.net/covid-19/news/safe-weber

Congratulations to Tiernan Greenman, a senior at Fremont High School, for winning the Nacel Open Door Congress-Bundestag Youth Exchange Vocational Scholarship, a national contest.

Tiernan will have the privilege to spend an enriching and rewarding year in Germany to perfect his language skills and learn a vocation. He hopes to get his internship in film studies or IT.

A product of Weber School District, Tiernan studied German at Rocky Mountain Jr. High for three years with Jordan Reichard, two years at Fremont High with Carolyn Sandstrom, and his last year at Fremont High with Seth Jones. Tiernan was also a German Camp Assistant during the summer of 2018 and went on GAPP (German American Partnership Program) as a student lead in 2019.

Thank you, teachers and parents, for preparing our fine young people like Tiernan and others to go out into the world and compete on a global stage. Congratulations, Tiernan; we wish you well on your journey.

Attention!

This afternoon, the Governor's Office and State Superintendent Sydnee Dickson announced a "soft closure" of all Utah public schools for a period of two weeks. This is in response to an enhanced statewide effort to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in our communities.

This means students are dismissed from traditional classes at all schools in Weber School District for a period of two weeks starting on Monday, March 16, 2020.

All schools will be closed on Monday, March 16th and Tuesday, March 17th, as teachers and staff make preparations for continued educational instruction for students through a modified home learning program.

Starting on Wednesday, March 18th, school campuses will be open to provide limited services, but students are still dismissed from attending classes. During this two-week period of soft closure, all extra-curricular activities and events are suspended.

More information will be sent out to parents and students as soon as it becomes available. Please understand this situation is constantly evolving and information is subject change.

Children who turn age 5 before September 2 may begin school with the 2020-2021 school year.

Weber High School’s Koby Pack takes 1st place at FBLA National Leadership Conference

Competing in San Antonio, Texas among 12,000 students in over 70 categories, Koby Pack, a Weber High student brought home 1st Place and the title of National Champion in the Sales Presentation Category.

Congratulations to Koby Pack led by Mr. Alan Rawlins, business/marketing instructor and FBLA advisor.

Although 105 individuals competed at the national leadership conference in the Sales Presentation event, it is not easy to get there or to get into finals. Only two percent of FBLA students advance to the national level, so just getting there to compete is a great achievement. For students to make finals at Nationals they must be in the top 2 of their preliminary section out of 13-14 students.

Koby took first place at the State competition in March out of 28 individuals where he had to finish in the top two to advance to Nationals. Along with Koby, 12 other students from Weber High also attended Nationals in a variety of other events.

Welcome to Silver Ridge Elementary

It’s official! Our new elementary school in Farr West will be named Silver Ridge Elementary.

After receiving input from students, parents and the community, two names were submitted to the Weber School Board for consideration. The Board selected Silver Ridge over Bayside as the official name of the new school. The name was chosen because of the beautiful views from the school of the Wasatch Mountains to the east and the Promontory Mountains to the west, and how the mountain ridges can sometimes appear silver in color.

The school, which is part of the $97 million bond that was approved by voters in 2017, is slated to open for the start of the 2019-2020 school year

DISTRICT DOESN'T TOTALLY SCRAP RECYCLING

Recently, Weber School District had to make some changes in our recycling efforts, but that doesn't mean we've stopped recycling! Schools like Country View Elementary continue to promote a very robust, community-based recycling program.

Students from the sixth grade classes help recycle cardboard and paper products every day. These materials are placed in seven Green Fiber recycling bins located in front of the school that are also available for use by the community.

The school receives hundreds of dollars each year for these recycled goods and the money goes toward purchasing trees that are planted in honor of retired teachers, maintaining an outdoor learning center, and helping to fund Eagle Scout and other school projects.

Weber School District will continue to promote recycling as much as possible, and examples like these teach us that we can still make a difference in our world!

CLEAN AIR

Did you know almost 3,000 students in Weber School District suffer from some form of asthma? On high pressure days this can be very problematic as air quality deteriorates due to smog and particle pollution.

There needs to be a greater collective effort to better protect the environment and our children’s health! In partnership with the Weber Morgan Health Department, Weber School District is launching a “Turn Your Key, Be Idle Free” campaign at all of our schools.

The goal is to reduce vehicle idling and unhealthy emissions while parents and others are dropping off and picking up students. The problem is particularly worse in the afternoons when vehicles are sometimes left idling for up to 20-30 minutes. This idling creates an area known as a hot spot, exposing children to higher levels of concentrated pollution.

We’re asking everyone to please help eliminate excessive emissions at our schools. The rule of thumb should be no idling for more than two minutes.

Thank you for all you do to keep our students healthy and safe!

CLEAN AIR

Did you know almost 3,000 students in Weber School District suffer from some form of asthma? On high pressure days this can be very problematic as air quality deteriorates due to smog and particle pollution.

There needs to be a greater collective effort to better protect the environment and our children’s health! In partnership with the Weber Morgan Health Department, Weber School District is launching a “Turn Your Key, Be Idle Free” campaign at all of our schools.

The goal is to reduce vehicle idling and unhealthy emissions while parents and others are dropping off and picking up students. The problem is particularly worse in the afternoons when vehicles are sometimes left idling for up to 20-30 minutes. This idling creates an area known as a hot spot, exposing children to higher levels of concentrated pollution.

We’re asking everyone to please help eliminate excessive emissions at our schools. The rule of thumb should be no idling for more than two minutes.

Thank you for all you do to keep our students healthy and safe!

Weber School District CTE has created a K-12 Teaching as a Profession pathway to help combat the teaching shortage. Our goal is to “grow our own” teachers. This program is part of the national Education and Training cluster. This program will offer students opportunities to explore careers in teaching, planning, managing, and providing education and training related learning support services.

The K-12 Teaching as a Profession pathway begins in the 9th grade with Exploring Education. The 10th and 11th grade classes are Teaching as a Profession I & II. In these courses students will explore teaching as a profession through hands-on experiences, gaining first hand knowledge of what it is like to be a teaching professional. As a capstone to the program, students will have the opportunity to earn concurrent college credit through Weber State’s Education 1010 course and can also participate in a Work Based Learning Internship in our district schools with mentor teachers.

FUN FACTS ABOUT THE BOND ELECTION

In November, a $97 million school bond was on the election ballot for Weber School District. The bond, which will not raise the tax rate, will fund a 12-classroom addition at Fremont High School, build a new elementary in Remuda in the Farr West area, build a new elementary in Pleasant View, rebuild Roy Jr. High School, and expand Weber Innovation High School. Here are some interesting facts about the bond election:

67,796 ballots were mailed out to registered voters

28,146 ballots were returned for a voter turnout rate of 41.5%

Out of all the ballots cast, 96.5% were received by mail

The bond passed with 58.6% of the vote

Weber School District has a history of going out for bond about every five to six years with previous bonds being approved by voters in 2000, 2006 and 2012.

Thanks to all those who participated in this year’s election. Work is already underway on the approved projects under the 2017 bond. For more information on the election go to www.weberelections.com

It was great to hear from people who love their careers or jobs, and make learning fun! Various speakers also talked about the need for collaboration, communication, and problem solving.

NEW EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION SYSTEM FOR RECEIVING TEXT MESSAGES

We are excited to announce the relaunch of the district parent communication and emergency system. Our engineers have been working hard to resolve the speed and reliability issues of the emergency notification system to better meet the needs of our teachers, parents, and communities. This new update will allow parents to receive text messages almost instantaneously, whereas in the past, there were some delays in receiving information.

To join, please log into MyWeber: http://myweber.wsd.net and click "Emergency Notifications" at the top of the page. Enter your cell phone, and you will receive a text to your phone. Reply to the text message with "YES" to confirm the phone is yours, and you're set to go!

To view these steps with screenshots, visit: http://wsd.net/parents-students/notifications/emergency-notifications

To report any issues with the system, please email myweber@wsd.net.

post_text: Earlier today, Uintah Elementary was evacuated to the Dee Events Center at Weber State University because of the fire. Many areas in the Uintah Highlands have been affected and access is restricted as firefighters continue to battle the blaze. Notifications will be sent out as soon as possible whether or not school will be in session tomorrow at Uintah Elementary. All other schools remain open but there may be some transportation issues at H. Guy Child, South Ogden Junior and Bonneville, with buses being unable to get into some of the evacuated areas. More information will follow.
